attributes.title: Kenya Immigration Attitudes Study – Somali Kenyan Anti-Terrorist Recording

q1.value: Kenya Immigration Attitudes Study – Somali Kenyan Anti-Terrorist Recording

q5.value: This research was made possible (in part) by a grant from Carnegie Corporation of New York. The statements made and views expressed are solely the responsibility of the author. We are grateful to our research team in Kenya, and especially Nicole Audette.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Terrorist attacks by jihadist groups are thought to exacerbate discriminatory attitudes and treatment against Muslim populations in Christian-majority countries. Often, Muslims writ large are painted as “univocal” --- monolithically violent fundamentalists by the media or politicians in cahoots with the terrorists. Local Muslim populations are sometimes suspected of being sympathetic to the cause of the terrorists. Such anti-Muslim mass sentiment can lead to harassment and discrimination towards Muslims by state agents (e.g., police, immigration policy). By contrast, it is more openly acknowledged that there exists heterogeneity in Christian beliefs – when a Christian fundamentalist commits acts of mass violence, Christians are not lumped together under suspicion as sympathists. Problematically, narratives about Muslims in Christian majority countries often do not include Muslims’ own narratives, in which they often condemn such terrorist attacks and jihadist groups. In this study, we examine citizen attitudes and policy preferences toward ethnic Somali Kenyans in Kenya. As part of the study, we examine the effect of hearing a Somali Kenyan condemn Al Shabaab in an experiment. Al shabaab is a jihadist group originating in Somalia’s failed state that has claimed responsibility for multiple successful and unsuccessful terror incidents in Kenya (e.g., Westgate Mall). Specifically, respondents hear a (real) Somali Kenyan stressing commonalities between Islam and Christianity and expressing sentiments that Al Shabaab is a common enemy. Such a treatment may lead Kenyan citizen respondents to be more accepting of and less discriminatory towards Somali Kenyan and prefer that Somali Kenyans remain in Kenya as part of the Kenyan citizenry (versus leave to Somalia). Kenya is an important context for studying these matters because less scholarly attention has been paid towards attitudes towards Muslim minorities in Christian majority countries in the Global South, as well as countries that from inception have been mixed Muslim-Christian. Most studies focus on European contexts where Muslims have more recently immigrated. Importantly, ethnic Somalis who are Kenyan citizens have constituted a portion of the Kenyan population since independence. Due to colonial boundaries remaining relatively fixed in the post-colonial era, a traditionally Somali land area continued to remain in Kenya (the Northeastern Province). Then President of Kenya, Jomo Kenyatta, was unwilling to give up this territory to Somalia upon independence – despite negotiations and eagerness by Somalia and citizens living in the Northeastern Province to reunite with Somalia. Subsequently, secessionist resistence ensued. Somali Kenyans have often been viewed by other Kenyans as “immigrants” or not an accepted part of the Kenyan population.

q16.value: We hypothesize that hearing the treatment (a) decreases discriminatory attitudes towards Somali Kenyans and (b) increases pro-Somali Kenyan policy preferences. For more details, please see the attached pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: For more information on the text of the treatment, describes our operationalization of the treatment variables, the outcome measures, and the moderators, and our estimation strategy, please see the attached pre-analysis plan.

q24.value: Vanderbilt IRB #170737; Dartmouth IRB #00030291; Kenyan research permit: NACOSTI/P/17/7385/17300

attributes.title: Formalization, Tax Appeals, and Social Intermediaries in Lagos, Nigeria

q1.value: Formalization, Tax Appeals, and Social Intermediaries in Lagos, Nigeria

q2.value: Jessica Gottlieb | Adrienne LeBas | Nonso Obikili

q5.value: This study is part of the EGAP II: Taxation Metaketa.

q9.value: Initial registration occured prior to assignment of treatment. An updated pre-analysis plan was submitted on 29 Oct 2018, which was prior to researcher access to outcome data.

q15.value: Across much of Africa, the informal sector accounts for up to eighty percent of the labor force and a similar share of overall economic activity, but this sector remains largely outside the regulatory and tax reach of states. State appeals can shift formalization and tax compliance, especially if appeals shift the perceived costs and benefits of formalization and compliance. The understanding of the conditions under which these appeals are effective, however, remains incomplete. Since 2006, Lagos State Government in Nigeria has launched a number of initiatives to increase the registration of taxpayers and the payment of income tax. These initiatives have been successful, generating a more than 400 percent increase in tax revenue over this period, and they have been accompanied by a significant expansion of state services delivery, even in the poorest areas of Lagos. The majority of the informal sector, however, remains outside the state tax net. To this point, tax enforcement efforts in the informal sector have been minimal. Furthermore, most current income tax contributions by small businesses and vendors has occurred through indirect payment to the trade and marketplace associations to which many members of the informal sector belong. The aim of this study is to assess how the informational content and framing of formalization and tax appeals shape behavioral and attitudinal response.

q16.value: Our pre-analysis plan lays out four main hypotheses families, as well as a set of secondary hypotheses. The three most important hypotheses are as follows. First, we seek to understand how the provision of information that affects the perceived costs and benefits of formalization impacts behavior. Our expectation is the impact of this informational treatment will be insufficient to significantly increase formalization rates in the absence of additional interventions. We hypothesize that the same is true for tax compliance. Second, we investigate how differential framing of tax appeals shifts both tax morale and tax payment. We expect that appeals will be more effective in shifting the perceived benefits of tax compliance, behavior, and tax morale when they are delivered by actors that are viewed to be more credible and when individuals' past experience is consistent with the message framing. Finally, we examine the effects of collective versus individualized receipt of tax appeals. Our expectation is that individuals will be more likely to change their compliance behavior and orientation toward tax when appeals are visibly delivered to other individuals as well.

q17.value: Our study proposes two interventions aimed at increasing formalization and tax payment by informal sector vendors located in Lagos marketplaces, the bulk of whom are operating small businesses with fewer than five employees. The two interventions generate six separate conditions, and treatment is assigned at the individual level. Vendors’ knowledge of the tax registration process, benefits attached to registration, and their own potential income tax liability is low. The first intervention therefore examines how provision of information and registration assistance by a local NGO affects formalization. The second intervention then examines how the effectiveness of tax payment appeals varies based on the framing of those appeals and the identity of the agent delivering the appeal. One of the significant features of this research site is the importance of pre-existing institutions that already play a role in mediating the relationship between informal sector workers and the state. Thus, in the second intervention, an individual vendor will receive a visit that stresses either the potential costs of non-compliance (punishment) or the potential benefits of tax payment (more public goods), but we also vary the identity of the agent delivering these appeals. Individuals will be randomly assigned to delivery by staff of Lagos Internal Revenue or by representatives of the vendors’ marketplace association.

attributes.title: The Rise of Majority-Ethnic Nationalism and Social Fragmentation among Marginalised Groups: Experimental Evidence from India

q1.value: The Rise of Majority-Ethnic Nationalism and Social Fragmentation among Marginalised Groups: Experimental Evidence from India

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Rising ethnic nationalism – a trend witnessed across the globe – threatens the material and symbolic status of ethnic minorities by questioning their status as ‘true’ national members. Facing a common threat is generally thought to unite threatened groups under a common banner, strengthening identification and enhancing cooperation. However, marginalized group members do not always respond to group threats in concert. On the contrary, a threatening environment sometimes results in weakened group commitment. Through behavioural games in a laboratory setting in the field, this study explores how exclusion affects social identity choices among Muslims in India, as well as when group members respond to exclusion by deepening their group commitment, and when this is less likely. By randomly assigning a prime that highlights the symbolic exclusion suffered by Muslims in the context of rising Hindu nationalism, and by assigning participants to high- or low-status groups as a function of their family's monthly income, we study the role of socio-economic status in conditioning responses to group threat.

q16.value: Hypotheses are included in the pre-analysis plan. We study whether (1) deepening exclusion enhances differences in social identification among high- and low-status group members, with low-status group members coming to identify more strongly with the nation/region. (2) deepening exclusion enhances differences in strength of group commitment among high- and low-status group members, with low-status group members acting less pro-socially towards other group members and whether (3) deepening exclusion leads low-status minorities to attach more weight to existing social distinctions. We will predict the probability of cooperation/levels of contributions among primed/non-primed participants of high and low status to in and out-group members.

q17.value: Through randomly assigning a prime devaluing the common group status, priming individuals with their high/low financial status and assigning the high/low status of counterparts in prisoner dilemma and dictator games and a game of gifting to NGOs.

attributes.title: Religious Organizations and Policy Promises: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Tanzania

q1.value: Religious Organizations and Policy Promises: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Tanzania

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This research is part of a broader project on the role of political activism by religious organizations in fostering the development of programmatic linkages between citizens and political parties in sub-Saharan Africa. Prominent explanations for the absence of programmatic politics are the low levels of information available to African voters and the inability of weak political parties to credibly commit to programmatic campaign promises (Fujiwara and Wantchekon 2013; Keefer 2007; Keefer and Vlaicu 2008, Pande 2011). When national-level religious organizations take positions on the important policy debates in a country, they may solve two obstacles to the development of programmatic politics – an informational problem and a credibility problem. The credibility problem is that parties may face little cost from failing to implement policy positions if elected. National-level religious organizations can plausibly solve this problem by providing an institutional structure that can hold parties accountable for reneging on their promises over time. The registered experimental design measures the effect of religious endorsements on the credibility of policy promises.

q16.value: I will test the following hypotheses: Main Effect: H1. Policy endorsement by religious organizations increases support for candidates promising to enact the policy. Heterogenous Effects: H2: Policy endorsement by religious organizations increases support for candidates promising to enact the policy among respondents belonging to the same religious group as the endorsing religious organization (due to the varied credibility of the endorser to the respondent). H3: Policy endorsement by religious organizations increases support for candidates promising to enact that policy if the candidates belong to the same religious group as the endorsing religious organization and/or are deeply religious (due to the varied credibility of the endorser in holding the candidate accountable). Credibility Mechanism Effects: H4: Policy endorsement by religious organizations increases belief that the policy change will actually be enacted by government. H5: Policy endorsement by hierarchical religious organizations or religious organizations representing a large proportion of the population increases belief that the policy change will actually be enacted by government.

q17.value: In order to test the hypothesis that national-level religious organizations solve the credibility problem involved in making programming promises, I will run a survey experiment in Tanzania that combines an endorsement experiment and a conjoint experiment design to examine whether endorsement by a religious authority makes policy promises more credible. In the context of a household survey in 5 regions of mainland Tanzania, respondents will be told either that a certain entity has proposed changing Tanzania’s policies so that foreign companies working in Tanzania are required to employ more Tanzanian staff. Respondents will be randomly assigned to be told either that “NGOs in Tanzania”, “the Tanzanian Episcopal Conference (Catholic Bishops Conference of Tanzania)”, “BAKWATA (National Muslim Council of Tanzania)”, “the Christian Council of Tanzania (Protestant Ecumenical Organization)” or all four entities have made the policy proposal. These statements do not involve any deception, indicating that other non-named organizations have also supported the proposal. Immediately after hearing one of the endorsements, the respondent will be asked to respond to a conjoint experiment in which they are asked to vote for a candidate that is either campaigning on policy changes or pork barrel politics. I will consider the effect of endorsements by religious authorities on respondents’ support for the candidate supporting policy changes, in addition to two additional outcomes: respondents’ expressed support for the policy change and respondents’ belief the policy change might actually be enacted.

q21.value: The sample size for this data collection project was determined by a power analysis for a separate experiment.

attributes.title: Policing and Collective Action: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Uganda

q1.value: Policing and Collective Action: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Uganda

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: An extensive literature within comparative politics, human rights, and conflict examines the relationship between collective action and repression. Many of these studies use observational data to study the effect of repression on collective action or vice versa. But these studies are limited in their ability to address the thorny challenge of endogeneity (i.e., does repression aect mobilization or does collective action a repressive behavior?). Additionally, these studies do not distinguish between 1) appropriate police action and excessive police force and 2) individuals' previous level of mobilization. Using a nationally representative survey of 2,000 Ugandans administered in July 2018, we investigate two questions:  first, how different police actions affect citizens' support for the police and willingness to engage in collective action; and second, whether these effects are conditioned by whether individuals are already mobilized and engaging in collective action. We further examine heterogeneous treatment effects to explore whether these effects vary by respondents' support for the incumbent, prior police interactions, region, and gender. By examining the politics of policing in an authoritarian context, we hope to provide experimental evidence for when state-violence triggers political backlash, increasing collective action and decreasing support for the security apparatus.

q16.value: This study examines two theoretical priors relating to repression and collective actions. Specifically, how excessive police force affects how civilians respond to police action? We examine the backlash and deterrence hypotheses: first, that excessive force will decrease civilians support and increase collective action; or second, that excessive force will deter collective action. Additionally, we consider how these effects are conditioned by whether individuals are bystanders of collective action or engaged in it.

q17.value: Respondents (n=2000) are randomly assigned to one of four groups (2X2) experiment: one control group and 3 treatment groups.

q24.value: Mildway Research ethics committee approval number: #REC REF 0204-2017

attributes.title: How Do Domestic Audiences Respond to Ratification of International Human Rights Agreements? A Survey Experiment on Thai Residents

q1.value: How Do Domestic Audiences Respond to Ratification of International Human Rights Agreements? A Survey Experiment on Thai Residents

q5.value: The author gratefully acknowledges research funding from the Australian National University.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q16.value: As compared to the control group, respondents who receive treaty ratification information will: • Perceive the Prime Minister more favorably; • Be less likely to think enforced disappearances are likely; • Believe Thailand to be more respected by the international community; • Believe that the Thai government cares more about its citizens. Other hypotheses are delineated in the pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: Average treatment effects, mediation analysis. If necessary, also via propensity score matching and/or Heckman modeling.

attributes.title: The political conditioning of economic perceptions in Uruguay

q1.value: The political conditioning of economic perceptions in Uruguay

q7.value: Research assistant of the Political Science and Sociology department of the Universidad Católica del Uruguay

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The objective of this experiment is to test whether individuals in Uruguay, when faced to new informatoion about sociotropic economic perfmormance, update their beliefs asymmetrically dependening on their political partisanship. If the partisanship bias is confirmed, then it directly affects one of the main principles of democracy, the electoral accountability. The theory of economic voting posits that economic perceptions are a key factor to explain political behavior. So, if the causality is reversed and the vote (or political partisanship) influence the economic perception, this means individuals form their evaluations in dependence of their prior partisanships, then electoral accountability is at risk

q16.value: H1: Individuals with a partisanship bond with the ruling party will reject negative information about the sociotropic economic performance, while they will be willing to update their beliefs to positive economic information. H2: Individuals with a partisanship bond with an opposition party will reject positive information about the sociotropic economic performance, while they will be willing to update their beliefs to negative economic information.

q17.value: In an online survey two treatments and one control group will be randomized at individual level. The treatments are the following: Treatment 1: Montevideo, MVD - In recent days, the National Institute of Statistics (INE) presented data on the unemployment rate, which averaged 8% in 2018, maintaining the upward trend. That is to say, in Uruguay there are more and more people who cannot get employment. In turn, this figure is higher than that of some countries in the region such as Chile or Mexico Treatment 2: Montevideo, MVD - In recent days, the National Institute of Statistics (INE) presented data on the unemployment rate, which averaged 8% in 2018, maintaining the downward trend. In other words, in Uruguay there are fewer and fewer people who cannot get employment. In turn, this figure is lower than that of some countries in the region such as Argentina or Brazil. For the data analysis a means test will be done.

registration_responses.q1: The political conditioning of economic perceptions in Uruguay
registration_responses.q7: Research assistant of the Political Science and Sociology department of the Universidad Católica del Uruguay
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: The objective of this experiment is to test whether individuals in Uruguay, when faced to new informatoion about sociotropic economic perfmormance, update their beliefs asymmetrically dependening on their political partisanship. If the partisanship bias is confirmed, then it directly affects one of the main principles of democracy, the electoral accountability. The theory of economic voting posits that economic perceptions are a key factor to explain political behavior. So, if the causality is reversed and the vote (or political partisanship) influence the economic perception, this means individuals form their evaluations in dependence of their prior partisanships, then electoral accountability is at risk
registration_responses.q16: H1: Individuals with a partisanship bond with the ruling party will reject negative information about the sociotropic economic performance, while they will be willing to update their beliefs to positive economic information. H2: Individuals with a partisanship bond with an opposition party will reject positive information about the sociotropic economic performance, while they will be willing to update their beliefs to negative economic information.
registration_responses.q17: In an online survey two treatments and one control group will be randomized at individual level. The treatments are the following: Treatment 1: Montevideo, MVD - In recent days, the National Institute of Statistics (INE) presented data on the unemployment rate, which averaged 8% in 2018, maintaining the upward trend. That is to say, in Uruguay there are more and more people who cannot get employment. In turn, this figure is higher than that of some countries in the region such as Chile or Mexico Treatment 2: Montevideo, MVD - In recent days, the National Institute of Statistics (INE) presented data on the unemployment rate, which averaged 8% in 2018, maintaining the downward trend. In other words, in Uruguay there are fewer and fewer people who cannot get employment. In turn, this figure is lower than that of some countries in the region such as Argentina or Brazil. For the data analysis a means test will be done.

attributes.title: Community-based Skills Training, Employment and Social Transformation: Evidence from a Field Experiment in Northern Nigeria

q1.value: Community-based Skills Training, Employment and Social Transformation: Evidence from a Field Experiment in Northern Nigeria

q2.value: Benjamin Crost | Oeindrila Dube | Marcus Holmlund | Eric Mvukiyehe

q5.value: Many thanks to Adam Smith International (Mafita Project Team) and DFID for making this work possible. Funding from DFID Nigeria is gratefully acknowledged. Also, thanks to the DIME team in DC and Nigeria for their invaluable inputs in making this study possible.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The UK Department for International Development (DFID) has funded the Mafita Program which delivers skills training intervention implemented by Adam Smith International, that aim to improve the economic opportunities of marginalized youth in the three Northern Nigerian cities of Kano, Kaduna and Katsina. Since the late 1970s, Northern Nigeria has been the site of religious and ethnic conflicts that have led to substantial violence and instability. These conflicts are thought to be fueled by the region’s high rates of poverty and unemployment, as well as its large population of marginalized urban youth. Particularly notable in this context are the Almajirai, children of poor families from rural areas who migrate to cities to study in Qur’anic Schools. Observers of the region worry that, due to their lack of economic opportunities, these youths become easy targets for recruitment by violent groups and criminal organizations. This study will evaluate the impact of a unique vocational training program delivered through Community Skills Development Centers (COSDECs) to over 900 young men and women. The program is unique in targeting highly marginalized individuals, including many Almajiri. The intervention utilized a classroom-based approach in which fully equipped workshops and production facilities were used to train students in select trades. The COSDEC intervention recruited participants in two geographic areas: the states of Kaduna and Katsina. The program recruited from six categories of beneficiaries in the pilot period: Almajiri, Adolescent Girls in Islamic and Quranic Education (IQE), Persons with Disabilities (PWDs), Orphans and Vulnerable Children (OVC), Early School Leavers (ESL), and Prison Inmates. Recruitment was based on two primary selection criteria: (i) being in the age bracket 15 to 24 years old, and (ii) living on less than N225.76 (about $0.65 in today’s exchange rate) per day.

q16.value: The proposed impact evaluation seeks to answer three questions. 1. Can the COSDEC training intervention delivered by the Mafita program increase the labor-market outcomes and economic well-being of marginalized youth? 2. Does this intervention induce changes in religious, social and political attitudes, and alter youth tendencies to engage in criminal and violent activities? 3. What—if any—heterogeneous impacts does the intervention produce? Our primary hypothesis is that the Mafita program will have positive effects on the primary and secondary outcomes listed below. The study will estimate the effect of the COSDEC intervention on a set of 7 primary and 9 secondary outcomes listed below. Primary outcomes 1. Income generating activities (in past 30 days) 2. Participation in political and religious violence. 3. Attitudes toward religious adherence and religious enforcement. 4. Female empowerment 5. Caregiver female empowerment 6. Anti-social behavior. 7. Generosity toward other religions: donation experiment. Secondary outcomes 8. Attitudes towards political violence 9. Religious social network (for the purpose of this outcome, a respondent’s social network is defined as the five people he/she spends the most time with) 10. Religiosity 11. Subjective well-being 12. Self-esteem 13. Skills 14. Assets and consumption 15. Job search behavior 16. Range of social networks (for the purpose of this outcome, a respondent’s social network is defined as the five people he/she spends the most time with)

q17.value: For the directly measured outcomes (all outcomes except 7) we will combine all survey responses related to an outcome into a mean effects index, following Kling et al. (2007). To do this, we will first express responses in terms of standard deviations from the control group mean. We will then sum all standardized responses related to an outcome into an index switching signs if necessary to ensure that the positive direction always indicates a “better” outcome. We will also report a robustness test using the method of Anderson (2008), which weights the index items by their inverse covariance matrix. We will also present estimates of individual indicators within each family to better gauge how various indicators contribute to overall effects within families. For certain outcomes, we will test the primary hypothesis only for the subsample of male or female respondents. Specifically, we will test the primary hypothesis for outcomes 2 and 6 (participation in political/religious violence, and anti-social behavior) only for the subsample of male participants. In addition, we will test the primary hypothesis for outcome 4 for the subsample of female respondents since the outcome is less relevant for men in this context. As part of the heterogeneity analysis, we will also report estimates for outcomes 2 and 6 for women and outcome 4 for men. For outcome 7, which is measured by a choice experiment, we will use the estimation procedure described in section 4.4 in the PAP attached. For each primary outcome, we will estimate one regression using the mean effects index as the dependent variable and adjust p-values for multiple comparisons by controlling the False Discovery Rate (FDR) using the step-up procedure proposed by Benjamini, Krieger and Yekutieli (2006). When examining individual indicators within outcomes we will control the FDR across indicators within the outcome.

q19.value: The pool of youth applicants comprised 1,824 individuals. 900 were randomly assigned to treatment while the remaining 924 were assigned to control. The endline survey also covers 1,019 unique caregivers who are part of the COSDEC study.

q24.value: National Health Research Ethics Committee of Nigeria (NHREC); NHREC Protocol Number NHREC/01/01/2007-19/10/2018; NHREC Approval Number NHREC/01/01/2007-11/11/2018

attributes.title: Observational Open Science: An Application to the Literature on Irrelevant Events and Voting Behavior

q1.value: Observational Open Science: An Application to the Literature on Irrelevant Events and Voting Behavior

q2.value: Matthew H Graham | Gregory Huber | Neil Malhotra | Cecilia Mo

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Extant frameworks to address the "replication crisis" have focused on replicating experiments, but important social science findings have also come from analyses of observational data. This pre-analysis plan describes an effort to improve the toolkit for determining the reliability of results from observational studies, which we refer to as observational open science. Leveraging the passage of time, we will conduct pre-registered replications of three highly cited studies that argue that "irrelevant" events affect voters’ evaluations of government performance: Healy and Malhotra (2010), Healy, Malhotra, and Mo (2010), and Achen and Bartels (2016).

q16.value: Healy and Malhotra (2010) - H1: Tornado damage is associated with lower incumbent vote share. - H2: Tornado damage is only associated with lower incumbent performance when no disaster declaration is issued. - H3: Tornado deaths are not associated with election outcomes. Healy, Malhotra, and Mo (2010) - H1: Controlling for game expectations, college football wins (losses) are associated with higher (lower) incumbent vote share. - H2: This effect is stronger in places where college football outcomes have a greater effect on voters’ well-being, which is measured as whether the college football team are high-attendance and championship teams. Achen and Bartels (2016) - H1: Abnormally high or low moisture levels are associated with lower incumbent vote share. - H2: This effect is stronger in rural areas.

q17.value: We will use OLS regression. For each study, we choose a regression from the original paper, devise our own preferred specification with regards to fixed effects, lags, and controls, and specify a test of the predicted heterogeneous effect. We will run each regression on both the set of years in the original study, and on all of the additional election data we have for that study at this time. We will also run each regression separately for presidential elections alone, as well as on pooled election results across presidential, Senate, and gubernatorial elections.

registration_responses.q1: Observational Open Science: An Application to the Literature on Irrelevant Events and Voting Behavior
registration_responses.q2: Matthew H Graham | Gregory Huber | Neil Malhotra | Cecilia Mo
